===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wp|lang=ja|ã‚¢ãƒ¦|é®}}
{{wp|Ayu}}
[[File:Ayu_no_Shioyaki.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|é®}} (''ayu'', ''ai''): the '''[[ayu]]''' or '''[[sweetfish]]'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ã‚ã‚†}}
From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=ã‚ã‚†|-}} of uncertain derivation.
* One commonly encountered etymology suggests that ''ayu'' may derive from {{m|ja|é¥—|tr=ae||[[host]]ing someone to a [[meal]]}}, in reference to the way that this fish may be used in Shinto [[offering]]s.<ref name="ateji"/> However, this would have been pronounced ''ape'' in ancient times, and while this ''ape'' did later become ''ahe'', and a shift from ''-he'' to ''-ye'' did occur in many terms during the {{w|Muromachi period}}<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>, the word ''ayu'' in reference to the fish appeared in the ''{{w|Nihon Shoki}}'' (720 {{CE}}), and is thus too old for this shift to have occurred.
* Another common etymology states that ''ayu'' may be from extinct {{w|Old Japanese}} term {{m|ja|è½ã‚†|tr=ayu||to [[fall]], as nuts from a tree; to [[flow]] down, as [[liquid]] in a [[stream]]}}, in reference to the way that ''ayu'' swim [[downstream]] to [[spawn]] in the [[autumn]].<ref name="ateji">'''1988''': ã‚ã¦å­—ã®ãŠã‚‚ã—ã‚é›‘å­¦ (''Interesting Ateji Trivia'', in Japanese), Freelance Trivia Writers, p.46, Nagaokashoten, Ltd.</ref> Some references<ref>Gogen Allguide, http://gogen-allguide.com/a/ayu_sakana.html</ref> suggest that this is not very eventful and that this etymology is therefore unlikely. However, there are terms specific to the ''ayu'' downstream migration, such as {{m|ja|è½é®|tr=ochiayu||''ayu'' [[migrate|migrating]] downstream to spawn}} and {{m|ja|é®è½ã¤|tr=ayuotsu||''ayu'' migrating downstream to spawn}}, suggesting that this event has been culturally important enough that the {{m|ja||è½ã‚†|tr=ayu}} derivation may be [[plausible]].
* Alternatively, this term may be borrowed from {{bor|ja|ain|sort=ã‚ã‚†|ã‚¢ã‚¤|tr=ay||[[arrow]]}} in reference to how fast the fish moves. See also obsolete Japanese reading ''ai'' below.

The kanji spelling {{ja-l||é®}} in reference to [[sweetfish]] is specific to Japan, probably in reference to the way the fish ({{ja-l|é­š}}) stakes out its territory ({{ja-l|å }}). There is another tale wherein {{w|Empress JingÅ«}} caught an ''ayu'' and thereby prophesied (also spelled {{ja-l||å }}) the outcome of a battle, but this is likely a [[folk etymology]]. In China and elsewhere, the {{ja-l||é®}} character refers instead to [[catfish]].<ref name="KDJ"/>

The kanji spelling {{ja-l|å¹´é­š}} is in reference to the common one-year [[lifespan]] of this fish.<ref name="KDJ"/><ref name="DJR"/>

The kanji spelling {{ja-l|é¦™é­š}} is in reference to its [[sweet]]-tasting [[flesh]].<ref name="DJR"/>
